questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Proverbs 1 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 2:1-11 aloud, focusing on the active verbs: 'receive', 'treasure', 'incline', 'apply', 'call out', 'seek', 'search'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'seek' and 'search' as metaphors for diligence in pursuing wisdom
Pay attention to the contrast between wisdom and the 'forbidden woman' (v.16-17)
The phrase 'fear of the Lord' (v.6) is a key term that appears in the context of wisdom

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the reader) does WHAT (seeks wisdom), WHERE (the spiritual journey), and WHY (to understand the fear of the Lord and avoid destruction).
tips: The active pursuit of wisdom as a response to God's gift (v.4-5)
The danger of the 'forbidden woman' and her house (v.16-17) as a warning against false paths
The promise of protection from evil and perverse speech (v.10-11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the metaphor of wisdom as hidden treasure (v.4), the protection from the forbidden woman (v.16), or the call to 'apply your heart' (v.4)?
tips: Wisdom as hidden treasure (v.4) resonates because it emphasizes the high value and effort required to find it
The warning about the forbidden woman (v.16) is striking because it shows the real-world consequences of ignoring wisdom
The command to 'apply your heart' (v.4) is practical and immediate, showing active engagement

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men/Israel about the value of wisdom and its protection from evil?
tips: Solomon's goal was to encourage a disciplined pursuit of wisdom that leads to life and righteousness
The theological significance is that wisdom comes from God and is a divine gift that protects the believer from destruction
This passage sets the foundation for the rest of the book of Proverbs by emphasizing God's role in wisdom

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The definition of 'forbidden woman', the concept of 'fear of the Lord', and the nature of wisdom as a gift from God.
tips: The 'forbidden woman' (v.16) is not a literal person but a metaphor for false teachings or relationships that lead to spiritual death
The 'fear of the Lord' (v.6) is not fear in the negative sense but reverence and awe that leads to obedience
Wisdom is a gift from God (v.4-5) but requires active pursuit and application, which can be confusing when the gift is already given

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, how can you actively seek wisdom as hidden treasure (v.4) by applying your heart to God's Word?
tips: Identify one area where you need to seek wisdom (e.g., relationships, decisions) and set aside time to study God's Word
Practice 'applying your heart' by journaling one insight from Proverbs 2 each day
Avoid the 'forbidden woman' by seeking wisdom before making decisions that could lead to spiritual harm

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the gift of wisdom and ask for protection from the way of evil as described in this chapter.
tips: Thank God for the gift of wisdom that He provides through Christ
Ask for courage to pursue wisdom as hidden treasure (v.4)
Pray for protection from the forbidden woman and the paths that lead to death

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 3:1-20 aloud, focusing on the contrast between self-reliance and trusting God.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'trust' in verses 3 and 5
Pay attention to the phrase 'with all your heart' in verse 3
Listen for the contrast between 'your own understanding' (v3) and 'the Lord' (v3)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize in your own words: WHO (Solomon and the young men/Israel) is being instructed, WHAT (to trust God rather than self-reliance), WHERE (in all your ways), and WHY (to avoid being led astray and to find blessing).
tips: Include the threefold warning: do not forget teaching, do not trust your own understanding, acknowledge the Lord
Note the promise of straight paths and abundant provision
Mention the blessing of wisdom being more precious than jewels

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: 'Trust in the Lord with all your heart' (v3), 'the Lord will make straight your paths' (v3), or 'the blessed one who finds wisdom' (v13-14)?
tips: 'Trust in the Lord with all your heart' emphasizes complete surrender, not partial trust
The promise of straight paths (v3) addresses the practical need for guidance in life's challenges
Wisdom being more precious than jewels (v13-14) highlights the value of God's wisdom over worldly treasures

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men and Israel about the importance of trusting God rather than human wisdom?
tips: Solomon's purpose was to equip young men with life-long wisdom that leads to true prosperity
The passage connects God's trust to the avoidance of spiritual blindness and the pursuit of righteousness
This teaching is foundational for the covenant community, emphasizing that God's wisdom is the source of all blessing

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this chapter are challenging to understand? Consider cultural context, Hebrew terms, or theological concepts.
tips: 'Do not be wise in your own eyes' (v5) means not relying on human reasoning to judge God's ways, which can be difficult in a world of relativism
The phrase 'the Lord by wisdom founded the earth' (v9) is a claim about God's creative wisdom that might be hard to reconcile with natural science
'Do not despise the Lord's discipline' (v11) refers to God's corrective actions that can be painful but are necessary for growth

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson of trusting God with all your heart to a specific situation this week?
tips: When facing a decision that seems overwhelming, ask: 'What does God's wisdom say?' rather than my own understanding
Practice acknowledging God in your daily routines (as in 'in all your ways') to keep your paths straight
Surrender a small area of control (like finances or relationships) to God, trusting His provision

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His wisdom and trust Him in your daily life.
tips: Thank God for the gift of wisdom that leads to life and prosperity
Ask for the courage to trust Him when circumstances seem difficult
Pray for the grace to not despise His discipline and to honor Him with your resources

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 4:1-34 aloud, paying special attention to the repetition of 'get wisdom' and the emphasis on the heart.
tips: Notice the phrase 'get wisdom' appears three times in the chapter (v.5, v.7, v.10)
The emotional tone shifts from urgent instruction (v.1) to the profound importance of wisdom (v.7-8)
The repeated phrase 'do not forget' (v.5) emphasizes the lasting value of wisdom

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (Solomon) is teaching, WHAT (the way of wisdom), WHERE (to young men), and WHY (to lead them in uprightness).
tips: Solomon addresses young men as his 'sons' (v.1)
The call to 'get wisdom' is the central command (v.5-7)
The path of uprightness is contrasted with the path of the wicked (v.18)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: 'Keep your heart with all vigilance' (v.23), 'Let your eyes look directly forward' (v.27), or 'Ponder the path of your feet' (v.27).
tips: The heart is the source of life (v.23), so guarding it is vital for spiritual health
Looking forward shows proactive faith, not dwelling on past mistakes
Pondering the path of your feet encourages intentional living in the present

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men/Israel about the supreme value of wisdom?
tips: Wisdom is the principal thing (v.7) - more important than wealth or possessions
Christ is the ultimate wisdom (as per the Christ connection provided) and the only one who can truly guard the heart
The straight path leads to life, while the crooked path leads to death (v.18)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The command to get wisdom, the meaning of 'springs of life', and the straight path versus the crooked path?
tips: 'Get wisdom' in ancient context meant practical knowledge for living, not just theoretical understanding
The 'springs of life' (v.23) is a metaphor for the inner spiritual vitality that comes from wisdom, not physical health
The 'straight path' (v.18) refers to the path of righteousness that leads to life, while the crooked path leads to destruction

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Apply the theme of guarding your heart (v.23) to a specific area of your life this week.
tips: Choose one distraction that is affecting your heart (e.g., social media, worries) and set a time to guard it
Practice 'keeping your heart vigilant' by reflecting on what truly matters to God each day
Ponder the path of your feet (v.27) by planning one intentional step forward this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the importance of wisdom and guarding your heart.
tips: Thank God for the wisdom He gives through Christ
Pray for the strength to guard your heart against distractions
Ask God to help you choose the straight path of life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 5:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the contrast in verses 3 and 8.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'her' in verses 3-4
Pay attention to the phrase 'do not go near the door of her house' in verse 8
The contrast between 'honey' and 'wormwood' in verse 3

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is warned, WHAT the warning is about, WHERE the danger lies, and WHY it matters.
tips: The son (young man) is the primary recipient
The forbidden woman's allure and the consequences of adultery
The house of the forbidden woman is the place of danger

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the honey vs. wormwood metaphor (v. 3), the phrase 'her feet go down to death' (v. 3), or 'keep your way far from her' (v. 8)?
tips: The honey/wormwood contrast shows how initially attractive but ultimately destructive
'Her feet go down to death' is a vivid image of the consequences
The command 'keep your way far from her' is practical and immediate

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men about the dangers of adultery and the importance of faithfulness?
tips: Solomon warns against the seductive dangers of adultery that lead to death
The passage emphasizes that God sees all and the consequences are severe
This warning is for the young man to protect his honor and life

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The metaphor of honey and wormwood? The concept of 'her feet go down to death'? The idea that God sees all?
tips: The honey/wormwood metaphor: honey represents the initial allure, wormwood the bitter end
'Her feet go down to death' is a metaphor for the path leading to destruction
The phrase 'a man's ways are before the Lord' (v. 18) means God knows our actions and consequences

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the warning to avoid the forbidden woman in your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you might be tempted to 'go near the door of her house'
Choose a specific action to 'keep your way far from her' (e.g., avoid certain places or situations)
Pray for God's help to stay faithful

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for protection from the forbidden woman and for faithfulness to God.
tips: Ask God to help you avoid the dangers of adultery
Pray for strength to keep your way far from the forbidden woman
Thank God for His watchfulness over your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 6:1-35 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the ant's diligence and the sluggard's laziness in verses 6-11, and the seven abominations in verses 16-19.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the Lord hates' (v.16-19) and the list of seven abominations
Pay attention to the ant's example of preparation in summer (v.6-11)
Note the warning about the fire in the lap (v.25-27) as a metaphor for reckless behavior

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is warned, WHAT they are to avoid, WHERE this wisdom applies, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include the sluggard (lazy person) as the target
Note the ant as a model of industry
Describe the consequences of the seven abominations (ruin, poverty)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the ant's preparation (v.6-11), the seven abominations (v.16-19), or the fire in the lap (v.25-27)?
tips: The ant's example is relatable and practical: working hard in the present to avoid future poverty
The list of seven abominations is memorable and covers common moral failures in ancient Israel
The fire in the lap is a vivid metaphor for how reckless behavior leads to immediate destruction

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men and Israel about avoiding folly and living wisely?
tips: Solomon emphasizes the importance of practical wisdom over reckless promises
He contrasts the sluggard's laziness with the ant's industry to show the value of preparation
The seven abominations are the key behaviors that lead to spiritual and social ruin

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The seven abominations list? The meaning of 'free yourself like a gazelle'? The connection between the ant and modern life?
tips: The seven abominations (v.16-19) are a list that may seem arbitrary without context; they are specific to ancient Near Eastern culture
'Free yourself like a gazelle' (v.1-4) is a metaphor for being quick and independent, but in ancient times gazelles symbolized swiftness and freedom from bondage
The ant's preparation (v.6-11) is a model for industry that may not be immediately obvious in modern contexts

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson about industry versus laziness (from the ant) to your own life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you are being lazy (e.g., procrastination, financial planning)
Plan small steps of preparation for the coming week
Avoid the 'fire in the lap' by not taking reckless financial risks or promises

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for wisdom that leads to industry and avoid the seven abominations. Ask for strength to be like the ant in preparation.
tips: Thank God for the ant's example of diligence and foresight
Pray for the grace to avoid the seven abominations (pride, lying, bloodshed, etc.)
Ask for help to be proactive in your financial and spiritual life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 7:1-27 aloud, paying attention to the seductress's wily speech in verses 11-12 and the young man's lack of warning in verses 1-2.
tips: Notice the repetition of the phrase 'the young man' (v.1, 6, 11, 15, 19, 20)
Pay attention to the seductive speech: 'My husband is away; come, let us take our fill of love' (v.11-12)
The emotional shift from warning (v.1-5) to the tragic outcome (v.13-27) highlights the danger

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is warned, WHAT the danger is, WHERE it happens, and WHY the seductress is dangerous.
tips: Include the young man lacking sense (v.1-2)
Note the seductress's wily speech (v.11-12)
Describe how she leads him to destruction (v.13-15)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the seductress's deception (v.11-12), the young man's lack of warning (v.1-2), or the path to Sheol (v.18-20)?
tips: The phrase 'wily of heart' (v.11) shows her cunning
The line 'her house is the way to Sheol' (v.20) is a powerful metaphor for spiritual death
The young man's follow like an ox to slaughter (v.13) illustrates his helplessness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men and Israel about the dangers of seductive speech and the importance of wisdom?
tips: Wisdom is the protective force (v.2-3) that guards against the seductress
The seductress represents the world's temptations that lead to death (v.20)
This passage calls for the young to seek wisdom (v.1-2)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The seductress's identity, the meaning of 'Sheol', or the contrast between the young man and wisdom?
tips: 'Sheol' is the Hebrew word for the grave or abode of the dead, not hell as in Christian terms
The seductress is not a literal prostitute but a metaphor for spiritual deception (v.11-12)
The phrase 'the path to Sheol' (v.20) emphasizes the spiritual death that follows unwise choices

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the warning about seductive speech to avoid the path to Sheol in your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you might be vulnerable to 'seductive speech' (e.g., social media, conversations)
Practice wisdom by seeking God's guidance before making decisions
Choose to 'keep my commandments and live' (v.1) by avoiding the trap

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for wisdom as a protection from the seductress. Ask for the courage to choose wisdom over deception.
tips: Thank God for the wisdom that guards us from spiritual adultery
Pray for strength to resist the seductive speech of the world
Ask for the grace to follow wisdom's path to life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 8:1-36 aloud, paying attention to the personification of wisdom speaking in verses 1-4 and 22-23.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I call' (v. 3) appears in the context of wisdom's invitation
Pay attention to the contrast between wisdom and those who hate her (v. 31)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (wisdom) is speaking to, WHAT (the call for wisdom), WHERE (the crossroads and the created world), and WHY (to lead to life).
tips: Wisdom takes her stand at the crossroads (v. 1) to speak to all people
The Lord possessed wisdom at the beginning (v. 22-23)
Wisdom's invitation leads to life (v. 31)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: wisdom's pre-existence (v. 22-23), her call to the crossroads (v. 1), or the life/death choice (v. 31)?
tips: Wisdom's statement that she was present at the creation (v. 22-23) shows her eternal nature
The phrase 'Blessed is the one who listens to me' (v. 31) emphasizes the immediate benefit of wisdom
The contrast in v. 31: 'Those who miss me injure themselves; all who hate me love death' highlights the life-or-death consequence

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men about wisdom and its role in life?
tips: Wisdom is eternal and created by God, not a human invention
Wisdom is essential for life and leads to blessing
The call to seek wisdom is a direct path to avoiding death

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The personification of wisdom, the pre-existence of wisdom, and the life/death choice in verse 31?
tips: In Hebrew wisdom literature, personification is common but may be confusing for modern readers
The phrase 'The Lord possessed me' (v. 22) means wisdom was created by God but is distinct and pre-existent
The statement in v. 31 that 'all who hate me love death' is a strong warning about the consequences of rejecting wisdom

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Wisdom calls us to a life-or-death choice. What specific area of your life requires you to seek wisdom this week?
tips: Consider a decision where you feel stuck and wisdom could guide you
Think about how you can 'watch daily at my gates' (v. 31) by seeking wisdom daily
Practice listening to wisdom by studying Scripture and seeking God's guidance

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for wisdom and ask for the courage to choose life through wisdom.
tips: Thank God that He is the source of wisdom (v. 22-23) and that wisdom leads to life
Pray for the strength to choose wisdom over death in difficult decisions
Ask God to help you listen to His voice (wisdom) and avoid the path of death

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 9:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between Wisdom and Folly's invitations.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Come' in Wisdom's invitation (v.3, v.5, v.10) and 'Stolen water is sweet' (v.11) in Folly's deception
Pay attention to the emotional tone: Wisdom's feast is joyful and life-giving; Folly's offer is seductive but leads to death

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Wisdom and Folly) does WHAT (invites people) WHERE (in the house of wisdom) and WHY (to lead young men to life or destruction).
tips: Wisdom builds her house and sets a table for those who will live by insight
Folly sits at the door of her house and offers stolen water (deception) that leads to death
The contrast: Wisdom's invitation leads to life; Folly's leads to Sheol (hell)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Wisdom's house (v.1-2), Folly's seductive offer (v.11), or the two paths (v.12-18)?
tips: The phrase 'the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom' (v.10) is central and practical for daily life
Folly's deceptive phrase 'stolen water is sweet' (v.11) contrasts with Wisdom's 'blessedness' (v.12) and shows the danger of false wisdom
The ultimate consequence: 'the dead are there; her guests are in the depths of Sheol' (v.18) emphasizes the cost of folly

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men/Israel about the path of wisdom versus folly?
tips: Solomon's purpose was to warn young men against the seductive but destructive path of folly and to encourage them to seek the fear of the Lord for true wisdom
This passage serves as a practical guide for choosing life: wisdom leads to life and prosperity; folly leads to death and destruction

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The personification of Wisdom and Folly, the meaning of 'stolen water', and the concept of Sheol?
tips: In ancient Hebrew, Wisdom and Folly are personified as women (a common literary device in Proverbs) to contrast two paths of life
'Stolen water' (v.11) refers to water that is not from a source of blessing but from deception (like the water of folly) â€“ it's sweet in the moment but leads to death
Sheol (v.18) is the Hebrew word for the underworld or grave; it is not the same as hell but represents the realm of the dead

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the invitation of Wisdom to your life this week? Specifically, how do you choose the 'fear of the Lord' over the 'stolen water' of folly?
tips: Identify one area where you are tempted to follow the 'stolen water' (e.g., shortcuts in relationships, quick pleasures) and choose the path of wisdom
Read Proverbs 9:10 and ask: 'How can I let the fear of the Lord be the beginning of my wisdom this week?'
Take time to 'set the table' for wisdom by studying Scripture and seeking God's guidance in your decisions

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for wisdom to choose the path of life and to reject the deception of folly.
tips: Thank God for the invitation of Wisdom and the promise that His fear leads to life
Ask for courage to reject the 'stolen water' of worldly pleasures and to follow the path of the fear of the Lord
Pray for the gift of wisdom to guide your decisions this week

chapters.chapterTitle: Proverbs of Solomon: Righteousness and Wickedness

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 10:1-22 aloud, focusing on the contrasts between the righteous and the wicked.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'a wise son makes a glad father' (v.1) and 'a foolish son is a sorrow to his mother' (v.2)
Pay attention to the contrast between 'righteous' (v.10) and 'wicked' (v.10)
Listen for the progression from family (v.1-2) to speech (v.10-12) to actions (v.13-15) and then to the ultimate hope in God (v.16-22)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is affected by these proverbs, WHAT the proverbs teach, WHERE this wisdom is applied, and WHY it matters for young men/Israel.
tips: Include the contrast between the wise son and foolish son (v.1-2)
Note the importance of diligence over laziness (v.4-5)
Describe how love covers offenses (v.12) as a key to harmony

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the wise son (v.1), the diligent hand (v.4), the mouth of the righteous (v.10), or love covering offenses (v.12)?
tips: The mouth of the righteous being a 'fountain of life' (v.10) is powerful because it shows that righteous speech brings life and blessing
Love covering all offenses (v.12) is especially relevant in today's world where we often hurt others without understanding
The contrast in v.12: hatred stirs up strife but love covers offenses - this is a universal truth that applies to all relationships

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men/Israel about the importance of righteousness and wisdom?
tips: Solomon aimed to show that righteousness leads to life and blessing, while wickedness leads to death and sorrow
This passage points to Christ as the ultimate righteous one whose words (the gospel) are life
The theme of love covering offenses points to the Christian idea that God's grace covers our sins

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The contrast between the righteous and wicked? The meaning of 'fountain of life'? Why does love cover offenses?
tips: In ancient Israel, 'righteous' (tsedeq) meant living in obedience to God's law, not just moral behavior
'Fountain of life' (v.10) is a metaphor for the wisdom of God that leads to life, not a physical fountain
Love covering offenses (v.12) is a call for active reconciliation, not passive tolerance

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you actively cover offenses in your relationships this week, based on the theme of love covering offenses (v.12)?
tips: This week, pick one person who has offended you and practice saying, 'I love you, and I want to cover this offense with love'
Focus on the practical application of love in your daily interactions with others
Start small: one act of reconciliation can have a ripple effect in your relationships

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about the theme of love covering offenses (v.12) and the importance of righteous speech (v.10).
tips: Thank God for His love that covers our offenses through Christ
Ask for the courage to speak and act with righteousness in your relationships
Pray for the grace to cover offenses in others and to be a source of reconciliation

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 11:1-25 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between false balance and just weight in verses 1-3 and the generous soul promise in verses 23-24.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the upright' and 'the crooked' (v.3)
Pay attention to the phrase 'generous soul' (v.24) and how it contrasts with 'riches' (v.11)
The phrase 'integrity' appears in v.3 and v.23

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (young men/Israel) is being addressed, WHAT (wisdom on integrity and generosity) is being taught, WHERE (in daily life and business), and WHY (to avoid disgrace and gain righteousness).
tips: Include the contrast between false balance and just weight (v.1)
Note the connection between pride and disgrace (v.2)
Describe the outcome of generosity (v.24) and the danger of trusting riches (v.11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the false balance (v.1), the humility that leads to wisdom (v.2), or the generous soul being made rich (v.24).
tips: The contrast in verse 1 between the false balance (abomination) and the just weight (delight) shows the Lord's preference for honesty in trade
The phrase 'the humble is wisdom' (v.2) is a powerful reminder that humility leads to understanding
The promise in v.24 that the generous soul will be made rich (not by money but by God's blessing) is a strong call to generosity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men/Israel about the importance of integrity and generosity in life?
tips: Solomon is emphasizing that true prosperity comes from righteousness and generosity, not from wealth or pride
This passage serves as a warning against the dangers of dishonesty and pride, and a call to live with integrity
The themes connect to Christ as the just weight and measure (v.1) and the generous one who gave all (v.11)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'false balance' (v.1), the connection between pride and disgrace (v.2), or the concept of 'generous soul' (v.24).
tips: In ancient Israel, a false balance was an unbalanced scale used for trade, which could deceive the poor and enrich the rich
The phrase 'pride comes before a fall' (v.2) is a common warning in wisdom literature about the consequences of arrogance

The promise that the generous soul will be made rich (v.24) might seem counterintuitive because it suggests that giving leads to material prosperity, but it's actually about spiritual and relational w

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: This week, practice integrity in your financial dealings by using honest scales (v.1) and be generous in your giving (v.24).
tips: Choose one area where you can be honest with your money (e.g., budgeting, avoiding dishonest trade)
Identify someone you can give to without expecting anything in return (e.g., a neighbor, a charity)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 14:1-34 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between wisdom and folly in verses 1-2 and the specific examples in verses 10-11, 15-16, and 20-21.
tips: Notice the repeated contrast: 'The wise woman builds her house' (v. 2) versus 'the foolish woman tears it down' (v. 2)
Pay attention to the phrase 'fear of the Lord' which appears in verses 27 and 29
The phrase 'tranquil heart' (v. 30) is a key term that contrasts with the 'aching heart' in verses 15-16

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the wise and the foolish) is involved, WHAT (building and destroying, the path of life), WHERE (in the community of Israel), and WHY (to encourage young men to choose wisdom and avoid folly).
tips: Include the contrast between the wise woman building her house (v. 1) and the foolish woman tearing it down (v. 1)
Note the 'way that seems right' but leads to death (v. 12)
Describe the role of the fear of the Lord as a fountain of life (v. 27)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the contrast in verses 1-2, the 'way that seems right' (v. 12), or the 'tranquil heart' (v. 30)?
tips: The contrast in verses 1-2: 'The wise woman builds her house; the foolish woman tears it down' shows the practical impact of wisdom on community life
The phrase 'a tranquil heart gives life to the flesh' (v. 30) is a powerful image of inner peace leading to physical health and long life
The statement 'the fear of the Lord is a fountain of life' (v. 27) connects the spiritual and physical dimensions of life

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men in Israel about the importance of wisdom and the dangers of folly?
tips: Solomon aimed to encourage young men to seek wisdom that builds a stable life, as opposed to folly that destroys
The fear of the Lord is presented as the foundation for a life that is both spiritually and physically secure
This passage serves as a warning against the self-destructive paths of folly and a call to choose the way of wisdom

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The contrast between wisdom and folly in the context of ancient Israel, the meaning of 'tranquil heart', or the relationship between the fear of the Lord and the fountain of life?
tips: In ancient Israel, building a house was a symbol of social standing and family stability; tearing it down represented social collapse
The phrase 'tranquil heart' (v. 30) refers to a state of mind that leads to physical health and longevity, not just emotional calm
The 'fear of the Lord' (v. 27) is a deep reverence and obedience to God, not fear in the negative sense (like terror)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of 'tranquil heart' (v. 30). How can you cultivate inner peace and trust in God this week?
tips: Practice daily gratitude to build a tranquil heart, as the wise person does
Avoid the stress of worrying about the future that leads to tearing down your life (as in the foolish person)
Seek God's peace in difficult situations by remembering that He is the fountain of life (v. 27)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the wisdom that builds and the folly that tears down. Ask for the gift of a tranquil heart and the fear of the Lord.
tips: Thank God for the wisdom that leads to building a stable life and the fear of the Lord as the foundation of life
Pray for the strength to avoid the foolish ways that tear down your life
Ask God to give you a tranquil heart that gives life to your flesh

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 15:1-33 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between gentle and harsh words, and the repeated phrase 'the eyes of the Lord are in every place'.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'soft' and 'gentle' in verses 1, 4, 18
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the verses: peaceful and watchful (v.3) vs. the tension of strife (v.18)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Solomon is addressing, WHAT he teaches about speech and heart, WHERE this wisdom applies (in the context of Israel), and WHY this matters for young men.
tips: Include the contrast between a soft answer and harsh word
Note the role of God watching (v.3)
Highlight the value of pure heart over wealth (v.10)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: 'A soft answer turns away wrath' (v.1), 'the eyes of the Lord are in every place' (v.3), or 'a gentle tongue is a tree of life' (v.4)?
tips: The phrase 'a gentle tongue is a tree of life' (v.4) is a powerful metaphor for how words can nourish or harm
The contrast in verse 1: 'a soft answer turns away wrath' shows the immediate impact of gentle speech
The declaration in verse 3: 'the eyes of the Lord are in every place' emphasizes God's constant presence and watchfulness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men/Israel about the power of gentle speech and pure heart?
tips: Solomon aimed to show that speaking gently and having a pure heart leads to God's favor and avoids conflict
The theological significance lies in God's active watchfulness and the idea that true wisdom comes from inner purity
This passage connects to the broader theme of wisdom in Proverbs: God's wisdom is revealed through righteous living

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The contrast between gentle and harsh words, the meaning of 'a dinner of herbs with love' versus 'a fattened ox with hatred', and the concept of God watching everywhere.
tips: The phrase 'a dinner of herbs with love' (v.17) is a contrast to material wealth, emphasizing relational value over possessions
The term 'the eyes of the Lord are in every place' (v.3) means God is aware of all actions, not just the visible or intentional ones
In Hebrew culture, 'a hot-tempered man' (v.18) could lead to family conflict, but the solution is patience and gentle speech

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice gentle speech in a situation this week where you might be tempted to speak harshly?
tips: Choose one interaction this week where you can respond with a soft answer (e.g., to a friend or family member)
Reflect on how a pure heart (intentional kindness) can lead to peace in your relationships
Pray for the strength to speak gently even when frustrated

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His watchful presence and ask for the strength to speak gently.
tips: Thank God that He sees and cares for every interaction
Ask for the grace to avoid harsh words and choose gentle speech in conflicts
Pray for a pure heart that seeks God's wisdom in speech and actions

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 16:1-19 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'the Lord directs the steps' (v.9) and the repeated emphasis on God's sovereignty.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the Lord directs the steps' (v.9) appears in the context of God's control
Pay attention to the repeated use of 'the Lord' (appears 20+ times in this chapter)
Listen for the contrast between human plans and God's purpose (v.9-10)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Solomon and the wisdom tradition) is speaking to, WHAT (God's sovereignty over human steps), WHERE (in the context of young men and Israel), and WHY (to prevent pride and encourage trust in God).
tips: Include the warning about pride leading to destruction (v.17)
Note the command to commit work to the Lord (v.10)
Describe the theme of God making everything for purpose (v.11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the phrase 'the Lord directs the steps' (v.9), the command to 'commit your work to the Lord' (v.10), or the purpose of the wicked (v.11).
tips: The phrase 'the Lord directs the steps' shows God's active role in our lives without human arrogance
Committing work to the Lord leads to established plans (v.10), which is a practical step of faith
The wicked are made for the day of trouble (v.11) shows God's ultimate sovereignty even in evil

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men and Israel about the Lord's role in their lives?
tips: Solomon was warning against human pride and encouraging trust in God's sovereignty
The passage emphasizes that God is the ultimate director of our steps, so we should not rely on our own plans
This is part of the wisdom tradition to help young men avoid the pitfalls of pride and sin

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of God directing steps, the purpose of the wicked, and the definition of pride.
tips: In Proverbs, 'directs steps' means God guides the outcome of our choices, not that He removes free will
The wicked are used by God for the day of trouble (v.11) to show His justice and to provide a lesson for the righteous
Pride (v.17) is defined as arrogance that leads to destruction, not just being proud of one's achievements

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Apply the theme of committing your work to the Lord (v.10) by choosing one task this week and praying for God's direction.
tips: Identify a task that you've been struggling with and ask God to direct your steps in it
Commit this task to the Lord by praying and trusting His guidance
Reflect on how this will help you avoid the pride that leads to destruction (v.17)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for directing your steps and ask for courage to commit your work to Him.
tips: Thank God for His sovereignty in your life and for directing your steps
Ask for the courage to commit your work to Him when it's challenging
Pray for humility to avoid the pride that leads to destruction (v.17)

Pay attention to the phrase 'the purpose in a man's heart' (v4) which is a key metaphor for hidden thoughts
Notice the warning against revenge in v8: 'Do not say, I will repay evil'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (young men/Israel) is being addressed, WHAT the verses teach about daily life, WHERE this wisdom is applied (in the context of everyday decisions), and WHY it matters (to avoid sin and seek God).
tips: Include the sluggard (v3) who fails to prepare in time
Note the contrast between the wise and the fool (v2)
Describe the hidden purpose of a man (v4) and how the wise draw it out

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the sluggard's failure (v3), the hidden purpose (v4), or the call to wait for the Lord (v8).
tips: The sluggard's story (v3) is relatable: many people procrastinate until it's too late
The phrase 'the purpose in a man's heart is like deep water' (v4) is a powerful metaphor for how we hide our intentions
v8: 'Do not say, I will repay evil' is a call to avoid revenge and trust God's timing

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon and others trying to communicate to young men/Israel through this passage?
tips: Solomon's goal was to teach practical wisdom for daily life, especially in avoiding sin and seeking God
The passage emphasizes that true wisdom involves understanding one's heart and trusting God rather than human systems (like measuring weights)
This passage prepares the audience for the coming of Christ (as per the Christ Connection) who is the only one pure and who can draw out the heart

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The sluggard's story (v3), the meaning of 'deep water' in v4, or the call to wait for the Lord in v8?
tips: The sluggard (v3) might seem like a minor issue, but it reflects a pattern of laziness that leads to poverty
The metaphor 'deep water' (v4) is not literal but represents the hidden depths of the heart that only the wise can access
The phrase 'wait for the Lord' (v8) is a call to patience and trust, which can be difficult in a culture that values quick revenge

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of the sluggard (v3) and make it concrete: Identify one area where you are procrastinating and plan to prepare for the next step.
tips: Identify one area where you are a sluggard (procrastinating) and plan to prepare for the next step
Reflect on a hidden purpose in your heart and write down one thing you can draw out through prayer
Choose one verse (v8) and commit to not repaying evil this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the wisdom to avoid drunkenness and strife. Ask for the strength to draw out the purpose in your heart through His Spirit.
tips: Thank God for the wisdom to avoid drunkenness and strife
Ask for the strength to draw out the purpose in your heart through His Spirit
Pray for the courage to wait for God's timing instead of taking revenge

chapters.chapterTitle: A Good Name and Training Children

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 22:1-29 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between a good name and riches in verses 1-2, and the instruction to train children in verse 6.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the Lord' in verses 1 and 2
Pay attention to the phrase 'train up a child in the way he should go' in verse 6
Listen for the warning about the borrower (verse 7) and the poor (verse 16)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being addressed (young men/Israel), WHAT wisdom is given (the value of a good name, training children, etc.), WHERE it is applied (in the context of daily life and society), and WHY it matters (to avoid the pitfalls of wealth and anger).
tips: Include the contrast between a good name and great riches (v.1)
Note the instruction to train children from a young age (v.6)
Mention the warning about not robbing the poor (v.16)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the value of a good name (v.1), the long-term impact of training children (v.6), or the promise that God will plead for the poor (v.16)?
tips: The contrast in verse 1: a good name is more valuable than great riches, which speaks to our modern obsession with wealth
The instruction in verse 6: training a child in the way he should go leads to lifelong obedience
The promise in verse 16: God will plead for the poor when they are robbed, which is a powerful reminder of divine justice

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon and others trying to communicate to young men and Israel through this passage?
tips: Solomon was writing as a king to guide the next generation in living righteously and in harmony with God's creation
The main point is that a good name and the discipline of training children in God's ways lead to lasting blessing and avoid the destruction of wealth and relationships
This passage also emphasizes that God treats the rich and poor equally and that we should avoid the negative influences of anger

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'a good name', the concept of 'the Lord is Maker of them all', and the statement 'the borrower is the slave of the lender'?
tips: In ancient Near Eastern culture, reputation was highly valued, but here Solomon says that a good name (in God's eyes) is more important than wealth
The phrase 'the Lord is Maker of them all' (v.1) emphasizes that God created both the rich and the poor, so they are equal in His eyes
The statement in verse 7: the borrower is the slave of the lender, means that the borrower is in a position of debt and vulnerability, which is different from modern concepts of borrowing

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson of training children in the way he should go to your life this week?
tips: Think about one child in your life (or your own childhood) and how you can be a positive influence
Set a specific example of godly behavior for them, even if it's small
Consider how you can train someone in your life by teaching them the right things without forcing

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the gift of children and for His wisdom in parenting. Ask for the courage to train children in the ways of God, even when it's difficult.
tips: Thank God for the blessing of children and for the opportunity to train them in His ways
Ask for the strength to be patient and consistent in teaching children
Pray for the poor and for God to be their advocate when they are oppressed

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 23:1-23 aloud, paying attention to the warnings against excess and the vivid metaphors.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'do not' (7 times) as a warning tone
Pay attention to the phrase 'riches sprout wings and fly away' (v.5) which is a vivid metaphor
The warning about wine (v.12-13) uses a strong image of danger: 'biting like a serpent'

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (young men/Israel) does WHAT (avoids excess) in WHERE (society) and WHY (to avoid spiritual and material harm).
tips: Include the warning about feasting with rulers (v.1-3)
Note the consequence of excess: riches flying away (v.5)
Mention the danger of wine (v.12-13)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the warning about wine (v.12-13), the phrase 'buy truth' (v.10), or the warning about a stingy man (v.4-5)?
tips: The image of wine 'biting like a serpent' is visceral and shows immediate danger
'Buy truth' (v.10) is a strong call to prioritize spiritual truth over material gain
The warning about not eating the bread of a stingy man (v.4) shows the importance of relationships

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men/Israel about avoiding excess and seeking true wisdom?
tips: Solomon emphasizes that true wealth is not in material possessions but in wise choices
He warns that excess leads to spiritual harm and that wisdom is more valuable than wealth
The Christ connection: Jesus as the ultimate 'truth' and the bread that satisfies

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The phrase 'riches sprout wings and fly away' (v.5), the meaning of 'stingy man' (v.4), or the role of wine (v.12-13)?
tips: 'Riches sprout wings and fly away' uses a metaphor for how wealth can quickly disappear through negligence
A 'stingy man' in ancient Israel might have been one who hoards wealth without sharing, but the warning is about the quality of relationships
The warning about wine (v.12-13) is a common caution in wisdom literature about the dangers of excessive drinking

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the warning about wine or excess in your life this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you might be tempted to overindulge in something (like social media, food, or substances)
Choose to 'buy truth' by seeking spiritual guidance before making decisions
Practice moderation in your consumption, especially in social settings

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His warning about excess and His provision of wisdom. Ask for the strength to avoid temptation.
tips: Thank God for His warning about excess and His provision of wisdom
Ask for the strength to resist temptation and choose truth
Pray for your family to avoid the pitfalls of excess (like in eating or drinking)

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men and Israel about the consequences of wisdom versus laziness?

This is a warning to avoid spiritual and economic decay by cultivating wisdom

questions.title: Difficulties

tips: 'Rescue those being taken away to death' refers to God's rescue from sin's death penalty, not just physical death
'Sluggard' in ancient Israel meant one who idles and does not work, leading to social and economic ruin
The proverb 'a little sleepâ€”poverty will come' is a short-term consequence of laziness, but the long-term effect is total destitution

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the phrase 'do not answer a fool according to his folly' (v. 17), the self-deception of the sluggard (v. 17), or the consequence of the lying tongue (v. 12).
tips: The phrase 'do not answer a fool according to his folly' is a clear command that avoids the trap of being like the fool
The sluggard's self-deception (being wiser than seven men) shows how serious the problem is
The warning about the lying tongue (v. 12) is a strong example of how words can cause harm

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men/Israel about handling foolish people and avoiding self-deception?
tips: Solomon emphasizes the danger of self-deception and the importance of wisdom in interactions
The passage warns against the consequences of being foolish and the need for humility
This teaches that true wisdom is not in self-deception but in recognizing one's limitations

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The phrase 'a lying tongue hates its victims' (v. 12), the self-deception of the sluggard (v. 17), and the comparison of the fool to snow in summer (v. 1).
tips: 'Hates its victims' is a strong metaphor that might be interpreted as the liar's intent to harm, not just lie
The sluggard's self-deception is a common human condition that we can relate to
The snow in summer is a metaphor for something that is out of place and doesn't belong

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson about not answering a fool according to his folly this week?
tips: When someone is foolish, avoid arguing and instead redirect the conversation
Be aware of your own self-deception as a sluggard (lazy in spiritual matters)
Pray for wisdom to handle difficult conversations without becoming like the fool

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for wisdom that helps us avoid the folly of the world. Ask for strength to not be like the sluggard in your spiritual life.
tips: Thank God for the wisdom to handle fools without being drawn into their foolishness
Ask for help to avoid self-deception and to be diligent in your spiritual walk
Pray that you won't be a sluggard in your faith

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Proverbs 27 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 28:1-28 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the wicked and the righteous, and the repeated phrase 'the righteous are bold' in verses 1, 11, 19, 22.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the righteous are bold' appears in verses 1, 11, 19, 22
Pay attention to the contrast: 'the wicked flee when no one pursues' (v1) vs 'the righteous are bold as a lion' (v1)
The repetition of 'whoever' in verses 2-28 shows the cumulative nature of righteousness

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being described, WHAT the righteous and wicked do, WHERE this wisdom applies, and WHY it matters for young men/Israel.
tips: Include the contrast between the wicked fleeing and the righteous being bold
Note the examples of the righteous (e.g., 'whoever walks in integrity') and the wicked (e.g., 'whoever conceals his transgressions')
The context is the land of Israel for young men

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the boldness of the righteous (v1), the power of confession (v13), or the fear of the Lord (v14)?
tips: The phrase 'the righteous are bold as a lion' (v1) is a powerful image of confidence and strength without arrogance
The contrast in v13: 'whoever conceals his transgressions will not prosper, but whoever confesses and forsakes them will obtain mercy' shows the immediate impact of confession
The call to 'fear the Lord always' (v14) is a foundational theme for lasting righteousness

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men/Israel about the importance of righteousness and boldness in the face of sin and adversity?
tips: Solomon emphasizes that true righteousness leads to boldness and confidence in God, not in worldly power
The chapter serves as a warning against self-reliance and the need for humility and confession
This wisdom is especially relevant for young men who are often tempted to act without proper guidance

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The definition of 'boldness', the role of confession, or the contrast between the wicked and the righteous?
tips: The term 'bold' (Hebrew: 'mehar') in this context doesn't mean reckless but confident and courageous in righteousness
Confession in Proverbs 28:13 is not about repentance in the modern sense but about acknowledging sin and seeking mercy through God's grace
The phrase 'the wicked flee when no one pursues' (v1) might be interpreted as passive, but in context it means the wicked are easily overpowered by sin's consequences

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the lesson of the righteous being bold in your life this week? Consider: when have you been timid in the face of sin, or when have you needed to confess and seek mercy?
tips: Identify one area where you've been hiding your sin (like procrastination or dishonesty) and confess it to God
Practice boldness by speaking truth to a friend or family member in a situation of sin
Read Proverbs 28:14 and ask God to help you fear the Lord in your daily decisions

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Ask God to give you the boldness of the righteous, to help you confess your sins, and to fear Him always.
tips: Thank God for the boldness that comes from righteousness
Ask for courage to confess your sins and seek mercy
Pray for the Holy Spirit to help you live in constant fear of the Lord

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 29:1-27 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between pride and humility in verses 1, 20, and 23.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'a man' in verses 1, 5, 20, and 23
Pay attention to the phrase 'stiffens his neck' (v.1) and 'lowly in spirit' (v.23) for contrast
The word 'blessed' in verse 18 emphasizes the reward for keeping the law

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (young men and Israel), WHAT (the consequences of behavior), WHERE (in the community of Israel), and WHY (to encourage wise living).
tips: Include the contrast between the proud and the humble (v.23)
Note the role of the king in establishing justice (v.4)
Highlight the importance of vision and restraint (v.18)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the contrast in verse 1, the king's role in verse 4, or the humility in verse 23?
tips: Verse 1: The consequence of stiffening the neck (resisting correction) is sudden and irreversible damage
Verse 23: Pride leads to downfall, but humility brings honor â€” a timeless truth for leadership and personal life
Verse 18: Without prophetic vision (God's guidance), people lose restraint â€” this connects to Christ as the prophetic vision

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men and Israel about the balance between discipline and vision?
tips: Solomon emphasizes that discipline (reproof) is essential for growth, but without prophetic vision (Christ), people lose restraint
The theme of humility leading to honor is a direct contrast to the pride that brings downfall
This passage prepares the reader for the coming of Christ as the prophetic vision that restrains sin

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'prophetic vision' in verse 18? Why does the king establish the land by justice? How does pride lead to lowliness?
tips: In verse 18, 'prophetic vision' refers to God's guidance through prophets (which Christ fulfilled) â€” not just a vision but active guidance
The king's role in justice (v.4) is a political context where leadership must be rooted in righteousness
Pride (v.23) is not just about self-importance but a spiritual condition that leads to spiritual and social downfall

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice humility this week by accepting reproof (as in verse 1) and seeking Christ as the prophetic vision (v.18)?
tips: Ask a trusted friend for specific feedback this week (like reproof) and act on it
Read a short passage about Christ as the prophetic vision (e.g., John 16:13) and apply it to a current situation
Choose one area where you feel pride and replace it with humility by thanking God for His guidance

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for the discipline that refines us and ask for Christ as the prophetic vision that restrains sin in your life.
tips: Thank God for the reproof that brings you to Christ
Ask for the humility to accept correction and the vision of Christ to guide your decisions
Pray for the strength to avoid pride and seek honor through humility

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 30:1-33 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of Agur's exhaustion and humility in verses 1-2.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I am weary, O God; I am weary' (v.1)
Pay attention to the rhetorical questions in verses 3-5: 'Who has ascended to heaven and come down?' etc.
Listen for the emphasis on God's word being true (v.5-6)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (Agur son of Jakeh) is speaking, WHAT (his questions about God's nature and his request for God's word to be true), WHERE (in the context of wisdom literature for Israel), and WHY (to highlight human limitation and the need for God's truth).
tips: Include Agur's admission of his inability to understand God's ways
Note the rhetorical questions about God's transcendence (v.3-5)
Describe his request for God's word to be true and for neither poverty nor riches (v.5-8)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Agur's admission of weakness (v.1-2), the rhetorical questions (v.3-5), or his request for God's word to be true (v.5-6)?
tips: The phrase 'I am weary, O God; I am weary' (v.1) - shows deep spiritual exhaustion and humility
The question 'Who has gathered the wind?' (v.4) - highlights the inscrutability of God's creation and the limits of human understanding
The statement 'Add nothing to His words' (v.5) - emphasizes the absolute authority and truth of God's word

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon and others trying to communicate to young men/Israel through the words of Agur?
tips: To remind the young that human wisdom is limited and we must rely on God's truth
To foreshadow Christ as the one who is both the Son of God (who descended and ascended) and the faithful Word of God
The passage emphasizes that God's word is without error and must be followed

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this chapter are challenging? The reference to God's Son? The meaning of 'neither poverty nor riches'? The three things Agur doesn't understand?
tips: The mention of 'God's Son' in a context of wisdom literature is a messianic hint (Christ) but Agur is speaking of the divine nature of God's Word (the Son)
'Neither poverty nor riches' refers to avoiding the extremes of materialism and the need for spiritual contentment (v.7-8)
The three things Agur doesn't understand (eagle, serpent, ship, man with a woman) are metaphors for complex aspects of life and creation

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'neither poverty nor riches' to your life this week? What situation requires you to avoid the extremes of materialism and focus on spiritual contentment?
tips: Reflect on one area where you're pursuing wealth or poverty
Practice gratitude for what you have without the need for more
Share the message of contentment with a friend or family member

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the theme of God's word being true and our limitation in wisdom.
tips: Thank God for His truth that we cannot add to
Ask for the strength to accept our limitations and trust His word
Pray for wisdom to see God's provision in the midst of life's challenges

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Proverbs 31:1-31 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the king's warning and the description of the excellent wife.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the excellent wife' (v1) is repeated for emphasis
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the description: dignified and active
The phrase 'far more precious than jewels' (v10) is a strong comparison of value

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who the excellent wife is, what she does, where she acts, and why she is considered excellent.
tips: She rises early in the morning (v11) to work diligently
She buys fields and provides for her family (v12-13)
She opens her hand to the poor and is clothed in strength and dignity (v15-17)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: her rising early (v11), her buying of fields (v12), her opening hand to the poor (v15), or her children calling her blessed (v30)?
tips: Her rising early: shows proactive dedication without being prompted
Buying fields: demonstrates financial responsibility and long-term planning
Children calling her blessed: reflects the positive impact of her character on her family

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Solomon trying to communicate to young men and Israel about the role of women and leadership?
tips: Solomon aimed to show the value of a woman who is wise, hardworking, and compassionate as a model for society
This passage connects the excellent wife to the church as the bride of Christ (the 'excellent wife' pictures the church adorned for Christ)
The main point is that true excellence comes from character and actions, not just external beauty

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The description of the wife's work, the cultural context of women in ancient Israel, or the comparison to jewels?
tips: The phrase 'give not your strength to women' (v1) is a warning to kings (young men) about not being dominated by women, but the rest of the chapter describes the excellent wife as a positive model
In ancient Israel, women had limited legal rights, so the excellent wife is an ideal that goes beyond typical cultural norms
The comparison of the excellent wife to jewels: jewels are valuable, but the wife is more precious because of her character and actions

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you embody the character of the excellent wife this week? Specifically, how can you be like her in your daily life?
tips: Start your day early (e.g., 5:00 AM) to do a task that benefits others
Give to someone in need (even a small amount) to open your hand to the poor
Reflect on how your actions impact your family and community

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the example of the excellent wife and ask for His strength to live like her.
tips: Thank God for the church (the excellent wife) being adorned for Christ
Pray for the courage to be proactive and compassionate like the excellent wife
Ask God to help you open your hand to the poor and provide for others
